intro: Stoebe vulgaris, commonly known as common selfheal, is a flowering plant native to Europe, Asia, and North Africa. It is a perennial herb that typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, featuring upright stems covered in fine hairs. The plant produces small, pink to purple flowers arranged in clusters at the top of the stems, which bloom from June to August. Its leaves are heart-shaped and have a slightly hairy texture, while the root system consists of a thick, fleshy rhizome. Stoebe vulgaris is known for its medicinal properties, particularly for its ability to promote wound healing and reduce inflammation.
